docs.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- The high price announced for gold today by the RFC was a factor in the grain and commodity markets on the Board of Trade here, and a rush of professional buying lifted grains sharply. Wheat at the top was up as much as 4 cents a bushel and corn 3 1/4 cents above yesterday's finish, recovering virtually all the loss sustained in the liquidation movement that started early this month.

docs.lead_paragraph: LONDON, April 28. -- Last week's break and the subsequent recovery in the dollar have aroused considerable discussion here. docs.lead_paragraph: The Committee for the Nation sent a telegram last night to President Roosevelt, urging him to raise the dollar price of gold from $35 to $41.34 an ounce as a means of offsetting the downward movement of commodity and security prices. docs.abstract: Sen Banking Com approves unanimously and without amendment Par Value Modification Act making formal devaluation of dollar by increase in price of gold to $38 an ounce from $35; bill to come up for floor consideration in Sen on same day HR Banking Com opens what is expected to be brief hearings on bill; no difficulty for legis is expected in either HR and Sen, and once-feared prospect of amendments appears to have vanished; Sen com action comes after Fed Reserve Chmn Burns urged passage of bill on grounds that failure to pass it soon could provoke renewal of disorderly conditions in financial mkts and place in jeopardy Group of Ten monetary agreement; Burns defends Fed Reserve against charges that it has driven short-term interest rates in US too low, thus checking possible return flow of dollars to US; emphasizes to com that gold bill will fulfill important commitment undertaken by US as part of Group of Ten agreement; holds realignment of currencies which Group of Ten agreement achieved is absolutely essential to reinvigoration of US foreign trade and eventual restoration of equilibrium in US balance of payments; says negotiated realignment of exch rates would have been unattainable if US had refused to consider change in par value of gold; contends that unfinished business of internatl monetary reform requires that US act without delay and that Cong will set stage for much needed progress in internatl monetary and trade areas

docs.lead_paragraph: Gold leaped today to its highest price on record while the dollar lost value in major European markets. Dealers in Paris bid gold up to a closing price of $136.58 an ounce, the highest price the metal has ever reached and more than triple the "official" price set by the United States of $42.22 an ounce.

docs.abstract: West Ger natl bank authorities, in move aimed at curbing depreciation of mark against dollar, which reached 5% at 1 point, on Jan 3 sells $38-million of dollar reserves and engages in what are believed to be more discreet official sales of dollar through banking network; move reptdly contributes to profit-taking in dollars in other Eur centers; dollar has risen against most Eur currencies to levels not seen in past yr, partly as result of energy crisis; money mgrs believe that US will be affected less by crisis than Eur and that its foreign trade figures will improve; price of gold on Jan 3 hits record high of $123.70 in official commercial trading; reached similar levels in London and Zurich but then sagged; French Pres Pompidou asserts that he believes US is 'worried' by recent advance in dollar, news conf; notes that expensive dollar would weaken Amer exports; adds that franc, which at one point on Jan 3 declined to value below 20c, is not weak currency and French export prices are 'generally competitive'; observes that higher petroleum prices risk 'handicapping France's balance of payments' and that French currency and gold reserves are 'not extremely high'; Frankfurt banking sources rept that Fed Reserve Bank of NY intervened in exchange mkts last wk, buying Swiss francs and Ger marks to slow dollar's rise; sources are unable to put precise figure on amt of Amer activity; assert that in addition to US moves, West Ger Bundesbank sold about $1-billion in concealed interventions since Dec 15 to check advance of dollar; Pompidou's remarks, together with apparent Amer and Ger actions, indicate that some internatl cooperative efforts might be under way to stabilize mkt conditions; illus of scene at gold mkt of Paris stock exch (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The value of the dollar fell sharply against other major currencies in heavy trading yesterday despite further signs of rising United States interest rates. Gold prices closed higher. In New York trading, the dollar plunged to 1.7725 West German marks from 1.7905 Friday. The dollar also lost ground against the British pound, with sterling priced at $2.3565, up from $2.3365 Friday. ''Trading was extremely hectic,'' one New York currency dealer said. ''I'd say the currency markets are in a state of flux and turmoil right now.''

headline.main: Gold Price Guides Altered

docs.snippet: The Administration changed its inflation control guidelines to reflect spiraling gold and silver prices. The Council on Wage and Price Stability announced it was altering the voluntary Government guidelines to allow jewelry makers and other producers

byline.original: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Administration changed its inflation control guidelines to reflect spiraling gold and silver prices. The Council on Wage and Price Stability announced it was altering the voluntary Government guidelines to allow jewelry makers and other producers of precious metal products to pass on some of the high cost of buying gold and silver. Under a complicated formula, companies that receive more than 1 percent of their revenues from the sale of gold and silver products will be allowed to raise prices.

headline.main: Commodities; Platinum's Link to Gold Price

docs.snippet: ONE of the mysteries confronting futures traders in precious metals in recent months has been the closing of the gulf between the prices of gold and platinum.   For many years the premium on platinum had been about $100 an ounce, largely because th

byline.original: By H.J. Maidenberg

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the mysteries confronting futures traders in precious metals in recent months has been the closing of the gulf between the prices of gold and platinum. For many years the premium on platinum had been about $100 an ounce, largely because the trade estimated the above-ground gold stock at about 50 years of current demand and that for the gray metal at five years. This may be so, but at last Friday's close of New York's Commodity Exchange, the active near December gold futures found the price at $621 an ounce, up $14 on the week. The active January platinum contract on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose $14.30, to close the week at $632.90 an ounce.

Gold climbed above $500 in New York for the first time since late February. The United States currency weakened as the prime lending rate of 17 1/2 percent spread through the United States banking system and as Government reports indicated the economy was slowing.

Gold prices were higher overseas and virtually unchanged in the United States. A dealer said the metal's price ''went higher for practically no reason'' early in the day in New York, but then ''collapsed in the last half-hour'' of trading on profit-taking before the weekend.

headline.main: Market Place; Bullish Case For Gold Price

docs.snippet: THE price of gold, a key barometer of the world's economic and financial system just a few years ago, has shown some signs of revival in recent weeks as the metal's price has moved generally higher - it was set at $445 at the afternoon fixing in Lo

byline.original: By Michael Quint

docs.lead_paragraph: THE price of gold, a key barometer of the world's economic and financial system just a few years ago, has shown some signs of revival in recent weeks as the metal's price has moved generally higher - it was set at $445 at the afternoon fixing in London yesterday, up from $406 on Nov. 23 and a recent low of $296 an ounce on June 21. It fell to $437 in later New York trading. Still, the recent increases are a far cry from the mania that surrounded the metal in 1980, when its price was as high as $850 an ounce on Jan. 20 and $700 in early October. Since then, disinflation - a slowdown in the rate of price increases - has become the buzzword in the financial markets, and prices have tumbled for a variety of commodities, such as oil, that were once avidly sought by investors as protection against inflation.

headline.main: Dollar Trading Mixed; Gold Price Up in U.S.

byline.original: By The Associated Press

docs.lead_paragraph: In volatile foreign exchange trading yesterday, the value of the American dollar rose overseas, only to retreat sharply in the United States as some American interest rates plunged. Gold, buoyed by concern over the impact of Mexico's debt problems on the international financial system, posted its second consecutive day of big gains. The metal traditionally serves as a haven for money in times of international unrest.

In Tokyo, the dollar reached its highest level in nearly five years against the Japanese yen. Dealers in Frankfurt said European hopes that American interests rates would show further substantial declines were replaced with fears that expected massive United States Government borrowing will keep upward pressure on interest rates. High American interest rates, by increasing yields on dollar-denominated investments, help raise demand for dollars over other currencies.

headline.main: GOLD PRICE GYRATES WIDELY

docs.snippet: The price of gold was on a roller coaster yesterday, rising in London, plummeting later in New York on a report that the Argentines had agreed to withdraw from the Falklands, and finally recovering somewhat on news that Argentina was still claiming

byline.original: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

docs.lead_paragraph: The price of gold was on a roller coaster yesterday, rising in London, plummeting later in New York on a report that the Argentines had agreed to withdraw from the Falklands, and finally recovering somewhat on news that Argentina was still claiming sovereignty. In European and New York trading, gold ranged in price from a low of $335.50 an ounce to a high of $367. The actively traded near June contract on the New York Commodity Exchange finally closed at $346.50 an ounce, down $14 from Thursday's close. Earlier in London, gold was fixed in the afternoon at $361.50, up $12 an ounce.

headline.main: Dollar Up on Rate Rise; Late Gold Price Slips

byline.original: By The Associated Press

docs.lead_paragraph: Gold's price tumbled more than $11 an ounce in New York trading yesterday after posting strong gains in Europe. The dollar, buoyed by higher United States interest rates, rose against most major currencies and reached a record high against the Italian lira in Milan. Gold began the day by extending a rally that had started in New York on Monday. It rose $12.45 an ounce in Hong Kong to $326.61 and then climbed to $322.50 an ounce in Zurich, up from Monday's $312.50 close in that city. In London, bullion wound up at $322.25 an ounce, up from $313 an ounce on Monday.

Rates on some short-term Treasury securities fell more than one-half percentage point yesterday.

byline.original: By The Associated Press

docs.lead_paragraph: The dollar fell in value yesterday in foreign exchange trading in the United States after hitting record levels against the Italian lira and rising against other major currencies in European trading. Gold, which sank to a 15-month low in Europe, was unchanged to 60 cents an ounce higher in the United States, closing at $375.50 an ounce in late trading in New York. Currency traders said the dollar fell in United States trading because of a slight drop in the key Federal funds rate, the interest charged on overnight loans among banks. Lower interest rates often weaken the dollar by making dollar-denominated investments less attractive.

headline.main: Dollar Declines in U.S.; Gold Price Up Slightly

docs.snippet: The dollar fell in value in foreign exchange trading in the United States yesterday, offsetting gains posted earlier in Europe. Gold prices edged higher.   Traders attributed the drop, which came late in the day, mostly to the Federal Reserve's ann

byline.original: By The Associated Press

docs.lead_paragraph: The dollar fell in value in foreign exchange trading in the United States yesterday, offsetting gains posted earlier in Europe. Gold prices edged higher. Traders attributed the drop, which came late in the day, mostly to the Federal Reserve's announcement that the nation's basic money supply had fallen by $1.1 billion in the week ended Oct. 5, an unexpected fall that could possibly result in lower American interest rates. Lower yields, in turn, make dollar-denominated investments less attractive.

headline.main: Dollar Rises Broadly; Gold Price Moves Down

byline.original: By The Associated Press

docs.lead_paragraph: The dollar staged a broad advance yesterday on world currency markets, climbing to a record level against the Spanish peseta, as traders remained preoccupied with the course of Federal Reserve Board policy and fears of further increases in United States interest rates. Gold prices drifted lower in quiet trading, winding up at $413.25 an ounce in late bidding at the Republic National Bank in New York, off $4.90 from the late bid Friday. Interest rates have climbed by about a percentage point in the last two months in the United States, and fears of a further rise have grown following a Fed announcement Friday of an unexpected $600 million jump in M-1, the basic money supply.

byline.original: By The Associated Press

docs.lead_paragraph: The dollar turned mixed in United States trading yesterday after rising against most other major currencies in European activity. Gold prices slipped, with the late quote at the Republic National Bank in New York $392.50 an ounce, down $1.50 from Tuesday. European dealers said demand for dollars there increased after the failure of a Common Market meeting in Brussels that was aimed at solving the European Economic Community's financial problems. But the dollar continued to come under pressure from the record deficit in the United States trade balance.

headline.main: OMAN'S PERFUME WITH A GOLD PRICE TAG

docs.snippet: MUSCAT, Oman    THE three kings of the Orient took frankincense to Bethlehem as one of their gifts to the infant Jesus. Two young Omani entrepreneurs have now taken it to Paris. Using Omani frankincense, French perfume expertise and British marketi

byline.original: By JUDITH MILLER

docs.lead_paragraph: MUSCAT, Oman THE three kings of the Orient took frankincense to Bethlehem as one of their gifts to the infant Jesus. Two young Omani entrepreneurs have now taken it to Paris. Using Omani frankincense, French perfume expertise and British marketing consultants, Sayyid Sami Hamed bin Hamood and his brother, Sayyid Badr Hamed bin Hamood, have been promoting Amouage, or ''waves'' in Arabic, a scent that they bill as the ''world's most expensive perfume.'' The company is a little over a year old, but its perfume-marketing gambit appears to be working. While unwilling to reveal revenues, Laurence Muskett, its British general manager, called sales ''most encouraging.''

headline.main: Surprise Drop in Stockpile Causes Gold Price to Jump

docs.snippet: Gold and silver prices jumped yesterday after the Commodity Exchange in New York reported an unexpected 8.5 percent drop in gold stockpiles at one of its certified warehouses.   The Comex said 208,424 ounces, worth about $74 million, were withdrawn
docs.lead_paragraph: Gold and silver prices jumped yesterday after the Commodity Exchange in New York reported an unexpected 8.5 percent drop in gold stockpiles at one of its certified warehouses. The Comex said 208,424 ounces, worth about $74 million, were withdrawn on Tuesday from the Chase Manhattan Bank in New York by unnamed depositors. Total stocks fell to 2,210,729 ounces, from 2,420,957 ounces on Monday.

headline.main: Bonds Slump as Gold Price Climbs

docs.snippet: Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as rising gold prices fueled concern that inflation would accelerate and heightened speculation that the Federal Reserve was poised to raise interest rates.   Gold prices surged yesterday, with the futures contra
docs.lead_paragraph: Treasury bond prices fell yesterday as rising gold prices fueled concern that inflation would accelerate and heightened speculation that the Federal Reserve was poised to raise interest rates. Gold prices surged yesterday, with the futures contract for December delivery rising briefly above $400 an ounce before closing at $399.60. The market action suggested that investors were buying gold as a hedge against inflation, which erodes the value of fixed-income securities like bonds.

docs.lead_paragraph: Gold prices jumped to an eight-week high yesterday on concern that production will fall in South Africa, just as demand is growing in China. "Gold is in a severe supply deficit," said Leanne Baker, precious metals analyst for Salomon Brothers Inc. She predicts that gold prices will rise to $500 an ounce during the current economic cycle.

headline.main: Market Place;1996's gold-price rise sets bulls, bears and bankers to predicting.

docs.snippet: THIS year's mini-gold rush has opened a split of Klondike proportions between the precious metal's bulls and bears.         To the bulls, it suggests that the market is finally awakening to a fundamental imbalance between rising world demand and fall

byline.original: By Paul Lewis

docs.lead_paragraph: THIS year's mini-gold rush has opened a split of Klondike proportions between the precious metal's bulls and bears. To the bulls, it suggests that the market is finally awakening to a fundamental imbalance between rising world demand and falling production that points to a further sustained rise in price. And that belief was supported by a sharp rally in gold that took it from $388.10 at the end of last year to $417.70 on the Commodity Exchange in New York earlier this month, its highest price in more than five years.

headline.main: Spot Gold Price Is Under $280 Briefly in London and New York

docs.snippet: For the first time in more than 18 years, the spot price of gold dropped below $280 an ounce in both London and New York yesterday as the fear of sales by central banks and low inflation continued to undermine the outlook for this precious metal.

byline.original: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time in more than 18 years, the spot price of gold dropped below $280 an ounce in both London and New York yesterday as the fear of sales by central banks and low inflation continued to undermine the outlook for this precious metal. Despite a record for the amount of gold used in fabrication in 1997, the spot price of gold plunged almost 24 percent last year and has continued its fall this year.

docs.abstract: Barrick Gold Corp, one of world's biggest and most profitable mining companies, is thriving despite dramatic drop in gold prices; company earned record $301 million in 1998 on revenue of $1.3 billion, even though average spot price for ounce of gold was $294, down from $332 in 1997; Barrick mined 5 percent more gold, lowered its operating costs by 12 percent, to $160 an ounce, and sold its output for average price of $400 an ounce by hedging--selling gold it had not yet produced; Barrick chairman Peter Munk comments; photo (M)

headline.main: As Gold Price Plunges, a Company Thrives

docs.snippet: The price of gold has fallen to levels unseen in more than 20 years. But that does not seem to faze Peter Munk, chairman of the Barrick Gold Corporation, one of the world's biggest and most profitable mining companies.    ''I'm not a gold bug,'' Mr.

byline.original: By TIMOTHY PRITCHARD

docs.lead_paragraph: The price of gold has fallen to levels unseen in more than 20 years. But that does not seem to faze Peter Munk, chairman of the Barrick Gold Corporation, one of the world's biggest and most profitable mining companies. ''I'm not a gold bug,'' Mr. Munk said. ''I didn't form Barrick because I love gold. To me it was a fabulous business opportunity.'' Even in the current market, he said, the company produces gold for less than half the price it gets, and ''to me, that's like paradise.''
